body:
Correct re the `QueryContext` and vis-specific `buildQuery` usage. We're going in the direction of approach 1. 

Approach 2 is also valid but it not going to be easy to figure out which `buildQuery` to use without giving each `formData` a `type` property indicating which viz they're intended for. And the `type` property is essentially the buildQueryRegistry.

Any opinion re approach 1 vs 2?

See another thread in the PR that Chris and I discuss. That might be helpful in shaping the restructure.
On Nov 15, 2018, 08:32 -0800, Christine Chambers <notifications@github.com>, wrote:
> @xtinec commented on this pull request.
> In superset/assets/src/query/buildQueries.ts:
> > @@ -0,0 +1,18 @@
> +import { FormData, getGranularity } from './formData';
> +
> +// TODO: fill out the rest of the query object
> +export interface QueryObject {
> +  granularity: string;
> +  groupby?: string[];
> +}
> +
> +// Build the common segments of the query objects (e.g. the granularity field derived from
> +// either sql alchemy or druid). The segments specific to each viz type is constructed in the
> +// buildQuery method for each viz type (see `wordcloud/buildQuery.ts` for an example).
> +// Note the type of the formData argument passed in here is the type of the formData for a
> +// specific viz, which is a subtype of the generic formData shared among all viz types.
> +export default function buildQueries<T extends FormData>(formData: T): QueryObject[] {
> Good question. This was also bothering me as I was writing this method up. It seems each viz-specific buildQuery would need to provide the query count to the generic one the # of common queries to construct.
> Thinking restructuring this..
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or mute the thread.

Both `1)` and `2)` seem like they require a `vizType` right? 

`2)` seems slightly cleaner to me than `1)`, but just slightly :)

Yes I did and no I don't from china.

I usually use mapbox in other versions, but stopped worked after the update.
@zhaoyongjie Can you describe what is this PR supposed to do? any screenshot to show difference?
thanks @graceguo-supercat for this fix!
code is updated per comment. also tested in dev environment...much faster!!

@michellethomas Agree. I updated the PR to only remove it completely from the tests loading. 
The `superset load_examples` command will continue to load all the data but when the `-t` flag or equivalent is added, it will add only the subset that's used in the tests.

regarding 1) and 2). Before I write the comment I thought 2 but after written, I think let's go with 1 for now. We can switch to 2) easily. Just write another function to do the look up. And most likely this function will only be used by `query` so I was like why bother creating a separate one then.
thanks for quick fix!

@akshayjamwal07 I came across this problem too. The default WEBDRIVER_BASEURL is http://0.0.0.0:8088/, which is the backend server address. Because the backend doesn't render the graph, so it is unable to locate the dashboard or chart.

In my case, change WEBDRIVER_BASEURL to the frontend address http://127.0.0.1:9000 will solve this problem.

Thanks

I've superset 0.28.1 version.

@mbadrADS Maybe you should create a new issue instead of asking in this closed issue?

You forgot to check these boxes: "I have checked the superset logs for python stacktraces and included it here as text if there are any.

 I have checked the issue tracker for the same issue and I haven't found one similar."

+1 on relative expressions showing what they evaluate too instantly in the control

About the inclusive `<=` right bound, I also believe it should be exclusive. One way to do proper change management on this would be to:
* offer the option to `<=` or `<` on the control itself
* set the default to `<` for future/new charts
* set value to `<=` for all existing charts

That way:
* backwards compatibility is maintained
* option is available 
* UI is clear about the behavior

A few notes:
* this is a very highly requested feature and the quality of the work is really good!
* this is the kind of feature that needs to get pulled to a branch and tested to properly reviewed
* we like when committers grow the scope of their contributions over time, it gives us more confidence that they'll be around to help maintain their code in the repo
* @timifasubaa volunteered to pull/test/review, happy to do a round too
* let's do a full security assessment and make sure people understand the implications when using the feature

The metric is simply used to overlay a bar chart in the drop down list of each filter column/field.
So the bar length is defined by the metric result.
Common use case is often to just use a COUNT(*) metric here, so the user gets a feeling on how much the application of a filter will affect the amount of records taken into account.
You could as well use a dummy metric of just "1" and end up with a selection that will solely show the distinct values without any further hint to the user.
